node.title: Starbucks workers vote for a union in upstate New York
node.description: More than 80 baristas and shift supervisors from three Buffalo-area stores approve/reject joining labor group.
node.content: ["Starbucks workers at a store in upstate New York have voted to join a union, a first for the coffee chain's more than 8,000 company-owned stores in the U.S.\u00a0", "The election result \u2014 the first of three to be announced \u2014 came from Tom Miller, a field examiner with the National Labor Relations Board's office in Buffalo. The ballot counting for two additional Starbucks stores in the Buffalo area continued Thursday afternoon.\u00a0", "Of 27 ballots cast, 19 favored joining a union and eight voted against it, Miller said Thursday during a counting that took place over videoconference.", "More than 80 baristas and shift supervisors from three Buffalo-area stores had voted by mail on whether to be represented by Workers United, an arm of the Service Employees International Union. The\u00a0election ended Wednesday.", "The National Labor Relations Board on Tuesday\u00a0rejected\u00a0an appeal by Starbucks to stop the counting of ballots. The company had argued that the election should include all 20 of the region's stores, which effectively would have required the union to sway a much larger pool of workers.\u00a0", "Labor board members wrote in their unanimous ruling that Starbucks had not met the burden of proof needed to override the NLRB's premise that a proposed bargaining unit consisting of one workplace is legitimate. Just because a bigger group of workers in the region might share a \"community of interest\" is not sufficient to disprove the agency's presumption, they wrote.\u00a0", "The union activity at Starbucks comes amid increased leverage for workers amid nationwide labor shortages and as a record number of Americans\u00a0quit their jobs. Organized labor is also drawing more public support. A\u00a0survey\u00a0by Gallup in August found approval of unions at a more than 50-year high, with 68% of Americans saying they favored unions.\u00a0 \u00a0", "Pro-union Starbucks workers say they are fighting for higher wages, improved staffing and training, as well as steady pay hikes for those who stay with the company for years.\u00a0", "Since the efforts to organize began, baristas at three additional Starbucks stores have also requested permission from the NLRB to vote on a union. A similar effort is under way among workers at a Starbucks in Arizona.", "Beyond its\u00a0appeal with the NLRB, Starbucks dispatched executives to Buffalo \u2014 including legendary former CEO Howard Schultz \u2014 to make the company's case that a union would make it harder for workers to pick up shifts at multiple stores. Starbucks has a \"network of company-operated stores that work together to create a better partner experience,\" Johnson stated in his letter.\u00a0", "Days ahead of federal officials setting the union vote, Starbucks\u00a0said\u00a0it would hike starting pay to $15 an hour as well as raise wages 5% for staff employed more than two years and 10% for those with the company more than five years.", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
